headline: Expedia Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good day, and welcome to the Expedia's Q3 2015 Earnings Call. Today's conference is being recorded. At this time, I would like to turn the call over to Alan Pickerill, Vice President, Investor Relations at Expedia. Please go ahead, sir.
componenttext: Good day, and welcome to the Expedia's Q3 2015 Earnings Call. Today's conference is being recorded. At this time, I would like to turn the call over to Alan Pickerill, Vice President, Investor Relations at Expedia. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you very much. Good afternoon, everybody. Welcome to Expedia's Financial Results Conference Call for the third quarter ended September 30, 2015. Pleased to be joined on the call today by Dara Khosrowshahi, Expedia's CEO and President; and Mark Okers
componenttext:
Thank you very much. Good afternoon, everybody. Welcome to Expedia's Financial Results Conference Call for the third quarter ended September 30, 2015. Pleased to be joined on the call today by Dara Khosrowshahi, Expedia's CEO and President; and Mark Okerstrom, our CFO and EVP of Operations.
The following discussion, including responses to your questions, reflects management's views as of today, October 29, 2015 only. We do not undertake any obligation to update or revise the information.
As always, some of the statements made on today's call are forward-looking, typically preceded by words such as we expect, we believe, we anticipate or similar statements. Please refer to today's press release and the company's filings with the SEC for information about factors which could cause our actual results to differ materially from these forward-looking statements.
You'll find reconciliations of the non-GAAP measures to the most comparable GAAP measures discussed today in our earnings release, which is posted on the company's IR website at ir.expediainc.com. I encourage you to periodically visit our Investor Relations site for important content, including today's earnings release and an updated investor deck.
As a reminder, we sold our 62.4% ownerships stake eLong on May 22, 2015, which is previously a consolidated entity of Expedia, Inc. For GAAP accounting resources, the results of eLong are included in our results through the day of the sale. In order to allow retail investors to compare our current results in the like-for-like basis with our historical results, our commentary in the earnings release and on this call is principally focused on our results excluding eLong. It should be considered in addition to the GAAP results on a fully consolidated basis.
Finally, unless otherwise stated, all references to cost of revenue, selling and marketing expense, general and administrative expense, and technology and content expense also exclude stock-based compensation and depreciation expense. And all comparisons on this call will be against our results for the comparable period of 2014.
With that, I'd like to turn the call over to Dara.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Alan. Third quarter was another a strong one for Expedia building on a very good results we saw in the first half of the year. It all starts with the integral growth, and ours was excellent. Room night growth of 36%, air tickets up 31% and car day
componenttext:
Thanks, Alan. Third quarter was another a strong one for Expedia building on a very good results we saw in the first half of the year. It all starts with the integral growth, and ours was excellent. Room night growth of 36%, air tickets up 31% and car days up 33% year-over-year. Excluding Orbitz, gross bookings grew 18%, revenue was up 15% and adjusted EBITDA grew 17% with a performance nicely about that we'd expected when we last spoke. Note, too, that we achieve these result despite considerable foreign exchange, revenue margin and deal expense headwinds. Our teams are executing well.
Let me quickly cover a few other key matters that I'm sure of are interest to all of you before handing it over to Mark. We are pleased to have closed the Orbitz contraction on September 17. The teams immediately began integration planning, working closely to determine how best to bring these 2 beating travel companies together. As we said before, over wide is a global business. And as such, is significantly more complex than our prior integrations. The bulk of the integration work is expected to take place over the next 9 months with certain business, such as Orbitz partner network and Orbitz for business, pushing out to a year or more.
That said, we're off to a strong start and the teams are working hard to bring the companies together as quickly and as efficiently as possible, making sure that our travelers and supply or distribution partners are all taking care of in the process.
We've decided to make the Orbitz.com and cheap tickets businesses onto the Brand Expedia platform, and we'll look to look for leverage opportunities across the Orbitz portfolio brands. Mark will cover the near-term financial expectations for the Orbitz business in his remarks. 
Our hotel supply position continues to improve and this year, we added 14,000 properties through our inventory, now up 29% year-over-year. We continue to invest in people, processes and technology across our supply organization and our on boarding new hotels in record time at higher quality than we ever have. We expect to see some variation and seasonality quarter-to-quarter and expect property additions in Q4 to outpace Q3. We continue to have aggressive plans for property growth over the long term.
Now I'm sure have questions regarding any potential impacts arising from recent developments in the TripAdvisor instant book product. To the extent that price launch participation accelerates in some book global penetration, we would anticipate additional volume pressure in the TripAdvisor channel. While certainly not a positive, TripAdvisor has been a shrinking share of our overall demand pull for some time. Note too TripAdvisor is one of our lower margin channel so the impact in profitably will most likely be muted. Lastly, I will tell you that we're very happy to have trivago, one of the fastest-growing major global hotel meta-brands as part of our family. You've seen us invest aggressively that ran and should expect the same moving forward.
Now a fundamental part of our strategy is to continue to develop our marketing and product efforts relating to our proprietary direct channels. There are 3 areas that I'd like to highlight today: Loyalty, mobile and attach. 
On loyalty, we continue to see good progress in terms of customer loyalty and repeat behavior. The Hotels.com rewards loyalty program, which recently surpassed the 20 million member milestone, continues to see strong growth and in fact, one of the fastest-growing marketing channels for that brand. Our Expedia plus rewards program now has over 12 million members and has launched in 27 countries just this year with 2 more to come by year-end.
Turning to mobile. Mobile web for us is about new customer acquisition and app is about cementing those new customers into loyal repeat users. We see great traction in both channels, especially on the conversion on product side with our OTA brands seeing a range of 40% to 60% of traffic and 20% to 40% of transactions booked on mobile overall. I think its safe to say that mobile has transitioned from being a profit headwind to the key component of our core offerings and a channel product where we see significant potential going forward.
Last and certainly not least, we have in our portfolio now the preeminent full-service OTA brands, such as Brand Expedia, Travelocity, Hotwire, Wotif, Orbitz, Cheap Tickets and eBookers, and that means lots of air shoppers. Today, not including Orbitz, we see over 7.5 billion annual air searches, which is likely to increase over time and drive real opportunities to upsell and to ancillary of product and fair offerings, as well as cross sell into hotels, apartments, vacation rentals, rental cars, car hire, local tours and activities, insurance and more. We've just scratched the surface here in an area where we believe we have substantial lead and a strategic advantage. Next on the agenda is to execute this very same playbook with rail. We're coding up a new rail product as we speak, which we plan to launch next year.
The vast majority of our profits come from our direct channels in efforts like these represent a strategic growth drivers of the company now and moving forward. We've have a terrific year so far and I'd like to take a moment to thank employees place for all of their hard work, job well done. A tremendous effort is improving our capabilities in our business each and every day. With that, I'll hand it to Mark.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Dara. One quick reminder before I get started. We sold our 62% stake in eLong on May 22, and financial results for that business are included in our GAAP results on a consolidated basis through that date. To aid in comparability and to focus on th
componenttext:
Thanks, Dara. One quick reminder before I get started. We sold our 62% stake in eLong on May 22, and financial results for that business are included in our GAAP results on a consolidated basis through that date. To aid in comparability and to focus on the parts of the business that are ongoing, our comments today focus on Expedia Inc. results, excluding eLong. 
The overall trajectory of the business remains strong with the third quarter probably consistent with the trends we've seen throughout the year, strength across our breadth of leading brands and across geographies continue with rare exception. Our core OTA segments, trivago and Egencia, are all having solid years with strong execution and good financial results.
Top line growth was again driven by robust unit growth across all major geographies. Room night growth remained strong for all of our major brands relative to first half growth rates, leading to global room night growth of 36% year-over-year, as slight acceleration from 35% last quarter. The inorganic impact from recent acquisitions added approximately 8 percentage points to global room night growth in Q3.
Note that due to purchase accounting rules, we don't recognize revenue or the related room night volume from acquisitions, which was booked prior to the close date. And therefore, the impact on hotel revenue and room night growth from Orbitz was de minimus. Domestic room nights grew 25% in Q3 while international room nights were up 50%. Revenue per room night was down approximately 15% this quarter while ADRs were down 6%. These metrics are similar to to those we've reported in Q2 and the factors influencing our room night economics are largely the same as they have been for a while. 
Foreign currency accounted for little more than half of the decline in revenue per room night, while deliberate reductions in hotel margins and to a lesser extent, the impact of our loyalty programs and other incentives accounted for the rest. We continue to be happy to trade some of our unit economics to drive volume and global scale.
Air revenue grew 19% on ticket growth of 31%, partially offset by a decline in revenue per ticket of 9%. We continue to see fast ticket growth for Brand Expedia on the back of the consolidation of the Air Asia Expedia joint venture and the benefit of innovating them on the platform. In addition, Orbitz contributed 6 percentage points to air ticket growth this quarter. 
Excluding all inorganic impacts, air revenue would have grow 4% on ticket growth of 19%. Our advertising and media business, which is made up of trivago and our Media Solutions group, continued growing nicely, with trivago growing stand-alone revenue of 27% or approximately 49% currency neutral. Media Solutions also grew at a healthy rate and Orbitz contributed 2 percentage points to add media growth this quarter. We continue to drive to our P&L that reflects an aggressive sales and marketing investment around the world to expand our global reach and drive long-term growth, both gaining scale and leverage another key expense categories.
Excluding the impact from Orbitz, the P&L we delivered in Q3 was consistent with this approach. Selling and marketing growing a bit faster than revenue with cost of revenue, technology and content and G&A growing slower providing leverage. Importantly, our results for Q3 also include the layering of the Orbitz stand-alone financials for the 14 days of the quarter that we own the business. As we told you to expect on our Q2 call, the impact from Orbitz on adjusted EBITDA was indeed negative in Q3, primarily as a result of purchase again impacts, which when taken with approximately $7 million of deal and integration costs resulted in a negative impact of approximately $17 million in adjusted EBITDA for the quarter. At the top line, Orbitz controverted $421 million of gross bookings and $19 million of revenue.
Now I'd like to cover our financial expectations for full year 2015. I will give some color on our expectations, both excluding the impact of the Orbitz transactions, or an apple-to-apples basis with prior guidance, as well as including the impact of Orbitz, so you can fully understand the relevant impacts.
Given performance to date and the trends we are seeing, we are now forecasting full year consolidated adjusted EBITDA growth, excluding eLong, of 12% to 15%. On an apples-to-apples basis, relative to prior guidance for Expedia, excluding eLong and excluding all impacts of the Orbitz transaction in Q3 and Q4, we are forecasting full year 2015 adjusted EBITDA growth to come in near the high-end of that range.
On the other hand, including all impacts of Orbitz for both Q3 and Q4, which were not included in our prior guidance, we expect full year adjusted EBITDA to be near the lower end of our range. In total, we expect the full year negative adjusted EBITDA impact from Orbitz of over $32 million with approximately $15 million coming in the fourth quarter. This includes integrated related costs, as well as Orbitz operating results, which as mentioned will be negatively impacted by purchase accounting rules.
Although we plan to give you more color on our Q4 call regarding the likely impact of Orbitz for 2016, I'm able to share some additional perspective today. Based on the current trajectory of Orbitz on a standalone basis, we believe the business would have delivered full year 2015 adjusted EBITDA of roughly $135 million, which we think is slightly lower than street expectations. However, with the benefit of the more detailed integration planning we've been able to do since the closing of the transaction, we now have a better view on synergy realization timelines, as well as run rate synergy potential. 
Though there's still much more work to do and details to iron out, what I can tell you is that we now believe that there is meaningful upside to the $75 million in run rate synergies that we project at the time we announced the transaction. We expect the synergies to layer in slowly in the first half of the year, ramping to near run rate by the end of 2016.
With that, let's move to Q&A. Operator, will you please remind participants how to queue up for questions?

headline: Expedia Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] We'll take our first question from Mark Mahaney with RBC Capital Markets.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] We'll take our first question from Mark Mahaney with RBC Capital Markets.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Two quick questions, Mark, one for Dara. Mark, how far are you from ending margin the reductions on the hotel side? Like when do you think you'll get to parity or where you want to get to? And then that 36% of growth in room night, you said 8% from acquis
componenttext: Two quick questions, Mark, one for Dara. Mark, how far are you from ending margin the reductions on the hotel side? Like when do you think you'll get to parity or where you want to get to? And then that 36% of growth in room night, you said 8% from acquisitions compared to the 35% last quarter? Can you just give us to apples-to-apples comparison versus last year -- last quarter i.e. ex acquisitions what, that growth rate would have been? And then, Dara, big picture, you know the question's come out Airbnb can you just talk about what kind of impact that having on your business material or not and how you think about them go being with them or if they are going forward?

headline: Expedia Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure, Mark, thanks for the question. In terms of margin reductions, we do expect them to continue through 2016. They will start to mitigate in the back part of the year. And then you've got some annualization of that. So I think will be well into 2017 bef
componenttext: Sure, Mark, thanks for the question. In terms of margin reductions, we do expect them to continue through 2016. They will start to mitigate in the back part of the year. And then you've got some annualization of that. So I think will be well into 2017 before we see ourselves in a position where that's no longer a significant headwind for us. With respect to room night growth, listen, on an apples-to-apples basis, organic around 28% really for both quarters, this quarter and last quarter. So we really see a really consistency and the strength of just the core business. Dara, you want to take the Airbnb?

headline: Expedia Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, as far as of Airbnb goes, he's can tell the results that any effect that Airbnb has had on us is immaterial at this point. It's -- we don't see it in that business. It's not affecting us directly at all. If anything, we think that Airbnb may be getti
componenttext: Yes, as far as of Airbnb goes, he's can tell the results that any effect that Airbnb has had on us is immaterial at this point. It's -- we don't see it in that business. It's not affecting us directly at all. If anything, we think that Airbnb may be getting a new class of consumer into travel. It's typically a lower price point. It's appeal to millennials, and we think that, based on different occasions, sometimes some consumers will opt for rental type inventory and sometimes, they will opt for hotels. And we think the hotel product is a great product and it certainly shows up in our numbers. That said, it is adding supply into the market, into the logic marketplace. And that supply is addressable to a certain portion of the population. So our belief is that it will put pricing pressure in certain markets, where you see a significant amount of Airbnb inventory. We have heard sporadically from some of our market managers that there are certain period so that would be absolute peak periods that where a town with a town would tiddly sellout where it's quite selling out, and actually, that translates into good news for us because we wind up having hotel inventory to sell and market to our consumers during a time where previously, we wouldn't have that inventory. So, so far, when we talk to, call it, the crew on the ground who really know what's going on in the business, they view it as a positive versus a negative. It's clearly product that's important for certain group of people. So we will look to build out our rental product over time. First order of businesses is the traditional hotel product, but we are adding apartment type product, and we'll continue to add it. I think, incrementally, it'll become more important part of our mix next year and going into the following years.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to Justin Post with Bank of America.
componenttext: We'll go next to Justin Post with Bank of America.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: A couple of questions that might help us think about the next couple of years. First, OTAs have been around 15 years, and yet you're growing domestic room nights 25%. Can you talk about the penetration of online bookings in the U.S. and then what they mig
componenttext: A couple of questions that might help us think about the next couple of years. First, OTAs have been around 15 years, and yet you're growing domestic room nights 25%. Can you talk about the penetration of online bookings in the U.S. and then what they might actually later? How much is going and how much room is still there? And then, secondly, the tech platform, I believe it were 2 or 3 years into it, price line arguably was 9 years into there, purchases in some of the other Booking.com platforms. But how much more room do you have to improve conversion or other things with that tech platform? Or do think you might be running out of room?

headline: Expedia Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure. As far as the OTAs ago, I just think that anyone now who is looking to travel or looking to research or book travel is going to look at OTAs. And I think we have become mainstream. The numbers that we see as far as online penetration are in the 40%,
componenttext: Sure. As far as the OTAs ago, I just think that anyone now who is looking to travel or looking to research or book travel is going to look at OTAs. And I think we have become mainstream. The numbers that we see as far as online penetration are in the 40%, 50% range. And while there is some -- you have to believe in the law of large numbers that online penetration is going to slow down. I think our brands are becoming more relevant. Our supply is getting better. Our sites are getting better and faster. Our service is improving. So it really does look like we are taking share from some of the smaller players who can't make the kinds of marketing and technology and customer service and loyalty investments that we can. So I think, at this point, it is a game of not just online penetration increasing, but also our gaining share versus a number of other players. Keep in mind that we are still just a single-digit percentage of total room night in the U.S. So we think -- we really think we have a long way to go. And the teams are executing well. This is the teams that are accomplishing this. On the tech platform, we look very carefully at what we call our run rate. We are obviously, are running thousands of tests that are powered by thousands of hypotheses by our product teams. And we look at our win rate versus, call it, neutral or a loss rate, we look at the average size of win. In other words, if we have a win, is it -- what does that look like on a percentage basis versus the base case? And our win rate and the average size of win continue at rates that are pretty darn attractive and conversion continues to be a tailwind. So while theoretically, we think that there's a high water mark that we might be hitting, we haven't seen it. I do think that our increasing our supply and increasing the quality of supply and just the number of hotels is kind of a new tailwind that we haven't seen in the past couple of years. So I think that the conversion is not only a factor of the product and the tech platform, but it's also a factor of the good work that our supply team is doing. I would add just one thing about the tech platform, one thing that really touched me about the tech platform is that step one was who the platform was really these experience that the consumer saw. That tech platform now is going down the stack. And for example, our tell your experience, the total so we are offering our hoteliers are improving rapidly. We are arming them up with so much more data or hoteliers can look up how many people are looking at the their hotel. How many people looked at their hotel in built on arrival hotel? They're able to do it on a website. They're able to do it through an app, et cetera. This tech platform is of the benefits that we're getting from the tech platform are much broader than just the consumer, and we think that we're just getting started on the other parts that typically don't get headlines, but are quite valuable.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to Naved Khan from Cantor Fitzgerald.
componenttext: We'll go next to Naved Khan from Cantor Fitzgerald.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Two questions, 1 sort of related to force on MacBook and precedent decision to participate in that. How do see your own participation certain of change on the Google Hotel product? And how do you see certain of price line persisted participation change in
componenttext: Two questions, 1 sort of related to force on MacBook and precedent decision to participate in that. How do see your own participation certain of change on the Google Hotel product? And how do you see certain of price line persisted participation change in trivago for community? And then, I had a question on China. Are you seeing any sort of changes in demand in China outbound?

headline: Expedia Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure. As far as of the instant book product goes, we have worked with Google very closely on their hotel product, various parts of their hotel product. And I think we talked about it previously that it was our intention to test and learn with Google on th
componenttext: Sure. As far as of the instant book product goes, we have worked with Google very closely on their hotel product, various parts of their hotel product. And I think we talked about it previously that it was our intention to test and learn with Google on their -- on the book on Google. We thought the branding, the clarity that they sent to consumers was right on. So it's our intent to test and learn with them, and we will let the data and what our consumer tell us essentially drive the long-term decision to their. As far as price participation on trivago, it's unknown. trivago is now pretty aggressively testing out a product that looks like instant book. We think there's a lot more clarity again on where the consumer is booking their travel. trivago is simply trying to optimize that path versus, let's say, gather consumer data, upsell and other stuff. So they are very, very focused on just optimizing that consumer experience in that moment. The test is happening in Germany. And so far, we like what we see. And many of Expedia brands are participating. And I think the trivago team is excited about rolling out that product. We see if price line participates or not.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, specifically on that, they're on 90% of their traffic on desktop in Germany, as live on the product 50% up. And they are looking forward, based on the encouraging results they've seen to starting to roll this out to English-speaking countries over th
componenttext: Yes, specifically on that, they're on 90% of their traffic on desktop in Germany, as live on the product 50% up. And they are looking forward, based on the encouraging results they've seen to starting to roll this out to English-speaking countries over the course of next year. So very promising. I will take your China outbound question. There's no major change for us. It's hard with a country that big witches growing travel so fast for us to perceive different movements either rate. Again, we are dissipating in China, booked through our Expedia affiliate network business that powers a lot of the leading players in China with our international hotel inventory also through Hotels.com, also through Egencia and trivago is tipping -- it's tipping its flip it's still in the water in China. And we are looking forward to implement in the broader commercial relationship that we have with Ctrip through the back half of this year and the beginning part of next. And so we do think -- at least for us, anyways, China outbound remains a very big opportunity, and we continue to like what we see there.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to Brian Fitzgerald with Jefferies.
componenttext: We'll go next to Brian Fitzgerald with Jefferies.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: You've mentioned before there are kind of 2 stages of leverage as you step through an acquisition integration. One is getting the brands onto the call and platform. And then 2 comes as the data starts to flow and you can learn and optimize. So just curiou
componenttext: You've mentioned before there are kind of 2 stages of leverage as you step through an acquisition integration. One is getting the brands onto the call and platform. And then 2 comes as the data starts to flow and you can learn and optimize. So just curious on the second point, with the recently completed integrations, where are we? And then, with the Orbitz integration, it sounds like the optimization timeline is consistent with these prior endeavors. You get on the platform and then be optimization comes over the course of 1 to 2 quarters. Is that the right way to think about it?

headline: Expedia Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think you broadly got it right. I mean, 2 that we are nearing the end of that process with our course Travelocity where we did the tech integration really through last year, and recited the market integration you speak of this year. I mean, we are
componenttext: Yes, I think you broadly got it right. I mean, 2 that we are nearing the end of that process with our course Travelocity where we did the tech integration really through last year, and recited the market integration you speak of this year. I mean, we are probably 3 quarters the way through the process with the Travelocity right now, and we like what we see. That's a brand that's continued to be a growth brand, lapping over everything. So very encouraging. Wotif is probably a quarter the way through. It's on the platform. We're training the marketing models. They've just launched the brand-new brand campaign in Australia, which we're pretty excited about. It's one of their biggest ever. And that's really aimed at returning that iconic brand to iconic status. And I think, listen, those are good parallels for Orbitz generally. That said, as Dara said in his prepared remarks, Orbitz is a bigger business. Orbitz is a more global business. Even if you look at Orbitz in cheap tickets, I mean, these are business that have been, I would say, compared with Wotif or compared with the Travelocity, a little bit closer to optimization already. And so I think for the Orbitz business, even though the playbook is the same, the caveat is that we could see when we flip it over to the platform, actually a moment where conversion might degrade and we actually have a little bit more of an optimization period to go through. So I think that's the caveat that we really don't know the answer to yet. But aside from that, I think it is very similar playbook.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: And the other thing to add with Orbitz is that where as with some of the other brands, Travelocity, Wotif, we put on our platform and that was it. There are some very interesting things that -- and technologies and processes at Orbitz team have developed.
componenttext: And the other thing to add with Orbitz is that where as with some of the other brands, Travelocity, Wotif, we put on our platform and that was it. There are some very interesting things that -- and technologies and processes at Orbitz team have developed. We love their loyalty program. So that is a feature that we will look to build on our platforms, but it's their idea, their conception, et cetera. And there are technologies that they're building around in research, around connectivity with various providers. Those are, again, super interesting technologies that they build. The talent there is really good. So I think while Orbitz will move on to the Expedia platform, we're going to look for Orbitz to improve the Expedia platform as well.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to Tom White with Macquarie.
componenttext: We'll go next to Tom White with Macquarie.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: You talked a little bit about attach rates for air. I was just wondering, have you guys seen sort of similar inflation in CPCs for air queries like we've seen in hotel over the past 12 to 18 months, be it from maybe the air carriers and consolidation in t
componenttext: You talked a little bit about attach rates for air. I was just wondering, have you guys seen sort of similar inflation in CPCs for air queries like we've seen in hotel over the past 12 to 18 months, be it from maybe the air carriers and consolidation in that space? Or is air clearest sheriffs keeper refer either significant traffic and hopefully, cross sell it? And then maybe just an update on trivago to profitably, can you kind of give us a sense of your view on long-term margins for that business and maybe a timeline for when you might be able to scale back the investment there a bit?

headline: Expedia Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure, sure. as far as air queries go, in general, air CPC tend to be lower than hotel CBCs and where revenue per unit tend to be significantly lower than hotel revenue per unit. We have not to date aggressively participated in variable channels in air bec
componenttext: Sure, sure. as far as air queries go, in general, air CPC tend to be lower than hotel CBCs and where revenue per unit tend to be significantly lower than hotel revenue per unit. We have not to date aggressively participated in variable channels in air because of the revenue and profitability per unit that air has averaged historically. We think that we are in a position now to participate more aggressively in some of these variable channels and the growth rates that we see those bearable channels are very significant, but off of small basis. So air tends to be much more of a direct business. So attach revenue tends to be higher-margin revenue, so to speak, but we're very much looking forward to participating more aggressively in variable channels on the air side. There are some variable channels such as Maeda in the U.S. on the air side where we can't participate based on some kind of deals, women's that Mena channels have with some of our air partners. So while I think there's growth in the variable channels for air, it's not going to quite look like what we see in the hotel product, but it is a nice upside versus where we are now.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: And then, Tom, just on trivago, listen, I think that what we look for in terms of the long-term profitability or what we look at, when looking at long-term Profitabilities, what we see in there in their major mature markets, markets like Germany, the U.K,
componenttext: And then, Tom, just on trivago, listen, I think that what we look for in terms of the long-term profitability or what we look at, when looking at long-term Profitabilities, what we see in there in their major mature markets, markets like Germany, the U.K, France, Italy. And what we see there is a margin structure that quite frankly, looks a lot like TripAdvisor. Essentially, it's a big media business and that's growing nicely with attractive margins. The phase we're in right now wherever continues to be an that we are able to take those profits and put them into new opportunities. The story continues to be told in the U.S, Canada and Australia. The growth rates in the U.S. continue to be very impressive and U.S. awareness is now up to one in every second Americans actually heard of trivago, coming from a point of obscurity in 2012. So we're really still in that investment mode. We do think that the U.S. market will start to mature probably into next year. But then we look at some of the other markets, where they've entered recently. I mean, Japan, for example, we're seen revenue actually what Drupal year-over-year, fivefold in Brazil in the Middle East, it's sevenfold in some places. So they're still continues to be pockets of real great opportunity for trivago. And we continue to be very willing to invest in that. But again, I think keep in mind here is that we do have the model, where we actually see what long-term profitability looks like. We're just in a mode right now we are we just have too many attractive investment opportunities to drop that to the bottom line.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Would could very easily turn that business into a profit business, and it's really about the incremental opportunity that we have for our next investment dollar. And at this point, trivago has been very strategic for us.
componenttext: Would could very easily turn that business into a profit business, and it's really about the incremental opportunity that we have for our next investment dollar. And at this point, trivago has been very strategic for us.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to Eric Sheridan with UBS.
componenttext: We'll go next to Eric Sheridan with UBS.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: One bigger question again going back to marketing channels. Appreciate the color on trip and book on Google. But how should we be thinking about the relative ROI you're seeing today across or marketing channels? How are you thinking about how that might d
componenttext: One bigger question again going back to marketing channels. Appreciate the color on trip and book on Google. But how should we be thinking about the relative ROI you're seeing today across or marketing channels? How are you thinking about how that might develop in the coming years or what that might mean for market leverage in the business?

headline: Expedia Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure, Eric. In general, our ROI in the various channels has been fairly consistent this year versus last year. The amount that we can bid in certain geographies such as Europe has gone down on a CPC basis because of foreign exchange. But our efficiencies,
componenttext: Sure, Eric. In general, our ROI in the various channels has been fairly consistent this year versus last year. The amount that we can bid in certain geographies such as Europe has gone down on a CPC basis because of foreign exchange. But our efficiencies, sometimes they'll go up, sometimes they'll go down based on the bidding dynamics of the auction on a local basis. But when we look at our overall efficiency this year versus last year in the larger channels in Google, in Trip, and trivago and some of the social channels, the efficiencies haven't changed much. What we do look for is channels that are significantly, call it, new customer acquisition channels. And then our capability of moving those new customers into repeat customers through, call it, direct channels. The more we are able to convert those customers, the higher kind of toll we're willing to pay for those new customers. And it's been a formal of it that has been going on for a while and it's pretty comfortable. So I'd say right now, things are pretty stable. The only, I'd say mutable -- notable new factory so that the mobile channels for us are beginning to become a more affordable, so to speak. We have to call it, 2, 3 years ago when we are bidding into mobile. We go into a substantial loss in order to build up, in order to test and learn, in order to gather data so that we could optimize that products. Those losses now are -- have been significantly mitigated. And while we are still in investment mode on mobile, it's become a -- it's a nice story on a year-on-year basis for us.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to Douglas Anmuth with JPMorgan.
componenttext: We'll go next to Douglas Anmuth with JPMorgan.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: I just want to circle back on instant book. It seems like participants recently from hotels and OTI who recently joined your seemingly getting more control over their brand and messaging and perhaps customer service than was originally contemplated in the
componenttext: I just want to circle back on instant book. It seems like participants recently from hotels and OTI who recently joined your seemingly getting more control over their brand and messaging and perhaps customer service than was originally contemplated in the service. So just trying to understand, still I guess, why it's not appropriate for you? And is there something in the dynamics of that could change that going forward? And then also, you talked about the platforms in terms of the Orbitz synergies. Could you just outline more the biggest sources of upside versus what you are originally expecting there?

headline: Expedia Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, listen, on the instant book basis, we think that the -- of the trend outlets a participants getting more control over their brand of the better customer experience of not being confused about where broken. booking think it's a positive trend. It Trip
componenttext: Yes, listen, on the instant book basis, we think that the -- of the trend outlets a participants getting more control over their brand of the better customer experience of not being confused about where broken. booking think it's a positive trend. It TripAdvisor continues to be a -- an important channel for us, and we are in constant discussions and dialogue with TripAdvisor. So based on how we see the treatments of instant book, we will make our decision. At this point, we're not in. But from a long-term perspective, this is certainly a product that we have to auction participating in. and will keep that option open. The snow reason that falls one way or another. And we'll keep revisiting it. At this point, you can see that our growth rates are very, very healthy despite, let's say, the short-term sense of that hazarded, which I think is a good long-term sense.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: And then, Doug, just in terms of Orbitz synergies one of the big decisions that we made recently, which opens up incremental opportunity, was the decision to put Orbitz.com and Cheaptickets.com on the Brand Expedia platform. And that opens up a bunch of o
componenttext: And then, Doug, just in terms of Orbitz synergies one of the big decisions that we made recently, which opens up incremental opportunity, was the decision to put Orbitz.com and Cheaptickets.com on the Brand Expedia platform. And that opens up a bunch of opportunities that go beyond what we said on the call initially, which was early access to our global hotel footprints, access to our technology platform potentially and reduction of some corporate cost. And really, what's opened up now is that once Orbitz and cheap tickets are the Brand Expedia platform, not only do they get access and get to ride on the test and learn machine that Dara has spoken about frequently run just all the test you do any product getting better and better, but they instantly get access to our global footprint, not only just global hotels, but air, car, occasion packages activities, et cetera. So the product and below gets widen. The other pieces of this of though or as we've got into the business, we've seen that they did have, and they spoke about it, fraud and chargeback problems. That's something that we can help them with instantly as part of the program. We do have a global customer operations team, which has truly global scale and has huge amounts of efficiency benefits. They will immediately go on to that. And then the cherry on top of all of this, as Dara said, is that we do have some great technology around some of the air technology they built, some of their loyalty technology that we really use to make our overall product better as well. So those are all the things of that add up. Of course, we don't know the exact amount get. we're not ready to update the exact amount. But what we do know is those things add up to what we think is a meaningful upside.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to Lloyd Walmsley from Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: We'll go next to Lloyd Walmsley from Deutsche Bank.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sticking with the Orbitz and the synergy team, can you just give us a sense. I think you said $135 million in standalone EBITDA. Orbitz kind of independent. It seems like that would imply a pretty quick improvement on their fraud issues they were facing.
componenttext: Sticking with the Orbitz and the synergy team, can you just give us a sense. I think you said $135 million in standalone EBITDA. Orbitz kind of independent. It seems like that would imply a pretty quick improvement on their fraud issues they were facing. How much of that will be kind of require the platform transition? And how much can you do even ahead of that? And then, as a follow-up to that, can you just give us a broad sense for how much of the synergy, maybe either using the 75 as a baseline or your revised projections, just how much would come from the revenue side on better terms from hotels or better air terms? And how much of that is going to be coming off the operating expense side? Clearly, they have a lot of none marketing operating expense they wouldn't seem to be able to come out of the business. What are the kind of pockets there that we should be thinking about?

headline: Expedia Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure. Well, I'll give you a bit of information now and then on our Q4 call, we will be able to give you some more detail because there's a fair bit of detail for us to walk through. On the 1 35. Listen, actually say that the Orbitz team has taken some ver
componenttext: Sure. Well, I'll give you a bit of information now and then on our Q4 call, we will be able to give you some more detail because there's a fair bit of detail for us to walk through. On the 1 35. Listen, actually say that the Orbitz team has taken some very positive steps to stave off the fraud problem that they have been facing. But we think we can help them significantly beyond that. So think they have Sam's a lot of the losses. But again, we think we can do that was -- keep the conversion benefits of that sometimes get hurt when you take certain steps to stop fraud. In terms of how much from revenue, how much from cost synergies? We're not going to provide a ton of detail on that at this point. Again, we're still working through the detail. Obviously, there is a cost component around public company cost it's around that we mentioned. And there are some redundant teams, if you will. But we're not really getting into too much detail. I would tell you, though, that we -- even though we think there is a cost reduction opportunity that will create synergies on paper for the deal case, it also presents a huge recruiting opportunity for us. We've got about a thousand opened position at Expedia that are -- in our base operating budget that we would guide you to. But we just got open position and we find that Orbitz is a very talented team. We're looking to place of that people that may find themselves redundant, which is many of those roles as we can. We do think we're going to have some meaningful technology and product capabilities in addition to Orbitz teams located in Chicago. And we think this is a win-win opportunity across the board.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015

headline: Expedia Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015

componenttext: I guess, one sort just sort of housekeeping question. Are there plans either through an 8-K or some other disclosure to cover the Orbitz results for the part of the quarter that wasn't included in your results? And then, looking at the growth differential between bookings and revenues, and I know you guys have to touch on this a couple different ways. Is there a path that you could see that would be to those numbers converging over time, largely thinking is there a way that, as the business stabilizes, you start to see revenue growth that more like your bookings growth?

headline: Expedia Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure, Heath, I'll take that. So we are not going to provide at this point information around the part of that quarter that was not part of our results. We will be putting our, in our investor presentationa page for that lays out the impact of Orbitz on ou
componenttext: Sure, Heath, I'll take that. So we are not going to provide at this point information around the part of that quarter that was not part of our results. We will be putting our, in our investor presentationa page for that lays out the impact of Orbitz on our results for the 14 days that they were part of it. And we'll also outline the guidance update that I gave on this call. But we aren't going to provide anything beyond that at this point. There is pro forma data in the Q that you can see the more other I can give you a little bit more color. In terms of growth differential between bookings and revenue, listen, the big driver there continues to be what we've been doing on the hotel side, is reflected in our revenue per room night. Big chunk of that is foreign exchange. But also, just the deliberate margin reductions we're doing. So as I said to Mark on the kickoff question, I think we're really well into 2017 before we expect to see those pressures abate. And I think, at that point, you could expect to see those growth rates converge. And then I would also say the bigger that trivago gets, that can be a tailwind for it as well. Because of course, they're not a gross bookings at all, they're just a net debt to revenue.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think revenue expert to air and hotel and then revenue mix between media and hotel are also separate factors. We'll get better if our air volumes slowdown, which doesn't seem to be happening at this point.
componenttext: Yes, I think revenue expert to air and hotel and then revenue mix between media and hotel are also separate factors. We'll get better if our air volumes slowdown, which doesn't seem to be happening at this point.

componenttext: Yes. And secondly, can you talk maybe a little bit more detail regarding your growth in repeat customers accelerating maybe ex of numbers? And relatedly, are you seeing growth or accelerated growth in conversions as well?

headline: Expedia Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure. On China, it's really too soon to tell as to how the Ctrip and Cherner transaction will affect, how those respective businesses are run. We think -- we are admiration for the Ctrip team has only increased with that deal we think that's strategically
componenttext:
Sure. On China, it's really too soon to tell as to how the Ctrip and Cherner transaction will affect, how those respective businesses are run. We think -- we are admiration for the Ctrip team has only increased with that deal we think that's strategically super, super smart. James, and Jane and team are clearly executing, not only well on the ground, but also strategically. And I think you also heard that the changes in the one child policy that I think Jim supported for a long-term. So that team is executing well on a number of fronts. We have a very strong relationship with the Ctrip as part of the eLong deal, with eLong. And also, we've been doing business with Cherner as well for a long time on all about business. So we think that our outbound volumes will continue with them. It's just too hard to tell at this point, as to whether the deal that was announced will have any effect on those volumes. We don't think so, but you never know until you know. As far as inbound volume goes, I'd say the same thing, there's plenty of inbound volume going into China as well. We haven't seen any material change, but since the announcement. But it really is early at this point. As far as of the growth in repeat customers, we don't disclose a bunch of data there, but I would certainly confirm that the growth rate of our repeat customers, if we look at it this year versus the way we were 3, 4 years ago, it's much more healthy than it had been. The -- and it's a natural factor in that we're bringing in more new customers from the variable channels. And so there's a mathematical factor and that they -- a certain percentage of them turn into repeat customers. And the activity that we have in our core product, loyalty, et cetera, is also improving our repeat rates, which is a very nice contributor to, call it, the core profit engine of the company. So the trends that we see there are certainly, good trends and something that we're much more focused on now than where we were call it 3, 4 years ago. 3, 4 years ago was kind of about product conversion reaching into variable channels. Now it's not only those machines but also increasing our supply base and then increasing our repeat customer base as well. 
And then I think you asked a question on conversion as well. Conversion continues to be a positive factor. We don't disclose how positive one way or the other, but it continues to be a nice tailwind for the business.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, sure. We are very, very, very,just in case you don't get it, very excited about our tour business. In this growing in triple digit rates. And it is -- the product has improved. That team has worked for a long time on improving that product, and it's
componenttext: Yes, sure. We are very, very, very,just in case you don't get it, very excited about our tour business. In this growing in triple digit rates. And it is -- the product has improved. That team has worked for a long time on improving that product, and it's a product front to back. And the product, as you know now is available in mobile. We feature the product on TV. And this is, as far as the technology revamp, et cetera, this product was really revamped and launched into the marketplace based on the new tech platform, really, this year. And the team has been optimizing aggressively. And it shows in the results. And I think we're very early. We think we've got many, many years going forward of our tourist product improving substantially and we're just starting. But I'm really excited for the team, and I can tell you the team is pretty pumped right now. As far as our vacation rental strategy, we touched on it. We think that's it's an important product. At this point, we are more focused on our core hotel product. It's kind of order of operations. And as you've seen this year, we have accelerated bringing in incremental new hotel inventory. And as we go down the path, especially going into next year, we think that we will start adding more vacation rental apartments, et cetera, inventory because we do think that fundamentally, it's a type of lodging that clearly customers are interested in. And if customers are interested in, we will look to offer it to them.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015

componenttext: We'll go next to Ron Josey with JMP Securities.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: So Dara, wanted to get your thoughts on just a rate parity requirements. Some of your paying country in France are talking about specifically. If hotels can offer low prices than Expedia, how do you compete with that? And then, also just quickly on your 5
componenttext: So Dara, wanted to get your thoughts on just a rate parity requirements. Some of your paying country in France are talking about specifically. If hotels can offer low prices than Expedia, how do you compete with that? And then, also just quickly on your 50% room night growth in international, When traverses specific that's driving that? So meaning, is there -- are you focused on one particular geography? Or is just better overall execution?

headline: Expedia Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure. As far as rate parity goes, we're comfortable with where we stand and we agree not to call kind of enforce rate parity provisions of that we had in our contracts. And I think we're generally in a good place with the eRegulators. Listen, our retail s
componenttext: Sure. As far as rate parity goes, we're comfortable with where we stand and we agree not to call kind of enforce rate parity provisions of that we had in our contracts. And I think we're generally in a good place with the eRegulators. Listen, our retail skin the skin their product on -- in our marketplace for free. It's an on-demand market base of that can be in the. They cannot be in it. They can put their inventory in, et cetera. And what we've found in our retail partners have found is that the better inventory they put into the marketplace, the better they perform. And they are completely free to do what they want. What we've seen is that hotels want volume. And in general, there's kind of a good self reinforcing mechanism going on. And our marketplace, as you know by our volumes, has gone stronger. Our relationships with our hotel partners in general has gotten better. And when we look at the quality of our inventory, the quality of our inventory has increased, not decreased, since some of these issues have come up. So we absolutely want to be supplier friendly. We want to be on-demand. And I think that as our partners experience our marketplace more, it's a marketplace that they want to participate in more. And I think our price decreases don't hurt either.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: And then, Ron, on the hotel room night growth. i would just remind you that the impact of the Brand Expedia Asia joint venture consolidation and Wotif are both tailwinds to this metric on an inorganic basis. That said, we are seeing pretty broad organic s
componenttext: And then, Ron, on the hotel room night growth. i would just remind you that the impact of the Brand Expedia Asia joint venture consolidation and Wotif are both tailwinds to this metric on an inorganic basis. That said, we are seeing pretty broad organic strength in a bunch of places, Eastern Europe a strong. Africa is strong. Japan, South Korea, Taiwan, Indonesia. I mean, these are all places that have growth rates that's our high double digits, in some cases, triple digits. So it's a mix of things. But just keep in mind the acquisitions to bolster that number.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think one interesting note on our international room night growth is that we're seeing an increase in international to international destination and especially call it travel closer to home. We -- I'd say, we are a great platform for international trave
componenttext: I think one interesting note on our international room night growth is that we're seeing an increase in international to international destination and especially call it travel closer to home. We -- I'd say, we are a great platform for international travelers. But our APAC to APAC business, our Europe to Europe business, our in-country business, a strong segment of our business on a room night basis. On an ADR basis, that actually puts a little pressure on our ADRs, which is as you start to move into business that's less international and more domestic, you tend to move into categories that are lower ADR. So we think that this long-term, this kind of shift in demand and supply is going to be a long-term room night positive, but will put some pressure on our ADRs. But we think overall, that's a more healthy marketplace.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015

componenttext: And so just in looking at the trivago revenue and also, the intersegment elimination, it seems as thought the last year, the lines of trivago has increased quite a lot between be Expedia portion. It's just that made a platforms become more to end? And how this is the dynamic change in terms of reliance as far as OTA meta? If you can maybe sort out a few years that will be very helpful.

componenttext: Sure, Ken. So on trivago, the Expedia brands and really sort of all the big brands in trivago are generally gaining share. It's an analogous of situation to what you see in the broader industry. I would say, though, particularly one of the things of that drives Expedia share gains and trivago's is the fact that they are expanding into markets where we are exceptionally strong. Markets like the U.S, Canada, Australia, for example. And so that just plays naturally into our strengths. But again beyond that, our performance in trivago is dictated by the strength of our platform, the conversion benefits we're driving, as well as of the capabilities of our teams and everyone -- the full teams across those functions are doing pretty darn well. Dara, do you want to take the second question?

headline: Expedia Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, as far as book. Listen, Price Line is our largest competitor. They are very strong competitor. As you know, they're awfully smart. So we look at everything that they do with a great degree of interest and we'd be stupid to act otherwise. So we'll tak
componenttext: Yes, as far as book. Listen, Price Line is our largest competitor. They are very strong competitor. As you know, they're awfully smart. So we look at everything that they do with a great degree of interest and we'd be stupid to act otherwise. So we'll take a look at how they participate in instant book. And they will certain we enter into our vocals barges can tell you what the answer is going to be.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Great. And then just in terms of meta players being some way to another to an OTA, I mean, does that going to change that dynamic over time? And and we're really it's all about the exclusivity of the supply that you have?
componenttext: Great. And then just in terms of meta players being some way to another to an OTA, I mean, does that going to change that dynamic over time? And and we're really it's all about the exclusivity of the supply that you have?

headline: Expedia Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Listen, I think that in this industry, you are getting various players and various experiences roll into each other in a way that is -- that has changed. And you're not going to have kind of clear delineations between experiences the way that you had. Rev
componenttext: Listen, I think that in this industry, you are getting various players and various experiences roll into each other in a way that is -- that has changed. And you're not going to have kind of clear delineations between experiences the way that you had. Reviews is something that's very big on our site right now. We talk about our review content. We had about reviews and how it affects our conversion. Review used to be something that was only in Tripadvisor. But look no, it's a big part of trivago. But it something that's core to our product. Just like something core to their product. They are more involved in the booking path. You've seen us and various players test with meta like product on the OTA path. So I think a lot of these experiences are getting melted together. This is an industry that -- we had a young person who recently joined our company, and I like to spend some time with them. And he said, "God, your industry has a many people competing with each other and working in others. There's more competition in your industry then I've ever seen." And sometimes, when you're in the middle of the industry, you kind of don't have that perspective. A lot of these experiences are coming together. We don't know exactly where it's going to shake out, but we're trying to optimize for the customer experience and our partner and supply experience. And I think so far, what we're doing is working, what TripAdvisor doing when you are Price Line is doing is working. I think the bigger players are going to keep growing. This is a usually fermented marketplace and I do think these experiences are coming together. We just don't know exactly where it's going to shake out. Our interest is pretty simple in keeping our consumers and partners happy.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015

componenttext: We'll go next to Kevin Kopelman with Alan and Company.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Can you just touch on how you're thinking about the real opportunity and what you're working on with the new real product that you mentioned?
componenttext: Can you just touch on how you're thinking about the real opportunity and what you're working on with the new real product that you mentioned?

headline: Expedia Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, listen, it's -- the product hasn't been launched. And I think you know by now that we test and learn this stuff. So fundamentally, rail is an incredibly important way to transfer a mechanism for consumers all over the world. It's super important in E
componenttext: Yes, listen, it's -- the product hasn't been launched. And I think you know by now that we test and learn this stuff. So fundamentally, rail is an incredibly important way to transfer a mechanism for consumers all over the world. It's super important in Europe. It's very important in the APAC regions. Hoping it will be more important in U.S. but it's not as large a factor in the U.S. So this is just a really important product. I think that it has been typically underinvested in as far as online travel agencies go because there is so much money in the product itself. But I think that as we have built up our attach platforms, having context after rarely consume is gone, I think it's going to give us a lot of upsell opportunity. And then increasing the frequency of touches with our travelers, we think is going to really increase loyalty, especially on the mobile side, both of which are really good things. So we do know exactly where this journey is going to take costs. But we think that it can add to this theme that you heard from us, which is air give us terrific context. This is where people is going, gives us a lot of opportunity for delighting them. And I think rail, which is pretty commonly used product, can be something very big over the next 3 to 5 years. We're going to start small, but we're getting started now.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: A couple of questions. First, just on trivago. I think [indiscernible] 37% last quarter about 27%. Anything specific there? Is it just real large numbers? And second, on Orbitz, traditionally, they've been softer or a little weaker in international and on
componenttext: A couple of questions. First, just on trivago. I think [indiscernible] 37% last quarter about 27%. Anything specific there? Is it just real large numbers? And second, on Orbitz, traditionally, they've been softer or a little weaker in international and on the hotel side. Anything you're going to do just really be on the Expedia platform will help Orbitz book on those areas?

headline: Expedia Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Aaron, So trivago, I would say it's a little of a large number. I mean, the U.S. is now their largest market. They are well deep into clean comps into the U.S. So that's a big factor. And remember, foreign currency is just a big headwind on this b
componenttext: Thanks, Aaron, So trivago, I would say it's a little of a large number. I mean, the U.S. is now their largest market. They are well deep into clean comps into the U.S. So that's a big factor. And remember, foreign currency is just a big headwind on this business. They are a euro-denominated business and foreign currency neutral 49% year-on-year growth. So we're still pretty happy with that. If that's a slowdown, we're okay with that. In Orbitz, yes, they are traditionally weaker. International Hotel, et cetera and also, product mix. Definitely, that something we can help them with. Having access to our global footprint of now over 270,000 hotels around the world having access to our international air and car and soon rail content can only help the Orbitz business. I think, as Dara mentioned, we become pretty darn good at attaching hotel to air tickets. And one of the great things about Orbitz is they got a ton of air traffic. So we think that's a good opportunity, which should help them on the hotel side as well.

headline: Expedia Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: We certainly saw a strengthening and a product mix shift with Travelocity when they came on to our platform, and we expect to see a similar shift. I think Orbitz on balance, was stronger and hotel than Travelocity was. So maybe we won't see as much upside
componenttext: We certainly saw a strengthening and a product mix shift with Travelocity when they came on to our platform, and we expect to see a similar shift. I think Orbitz on balance, was stronger and hotel than Travelocity was. So maybe we won't see as much upside. But we saw happen with Travelocity and hopefully we'll see it happen with Orbitz as well.
